Comments: Love Adams , love the waterfall, initial switchbacks are brutal but a great hike for all .
Hiked this today with our 4 and 6 year old. A couple tricky spots but overall not to bad with the kids and the waterfall was so worth it
Currently closed because of the Snoqualmie fire.

I did this trail on August 15th, 2019. It was described to be much more difficult than it actually was for me. I hit the trail at 0730 with a temperature of 59 degree F. I made my way up the few switchbacks, which are entirely exposed. Leaving early, I was never in direct sunlight for the ascent. Once you get to the top of the switchbacks, veer to the right to get to the falls. As I entered the brush into the canyon it was cool. Although every stop for photo ops meant getting attacked by mosquitoes, so do bring bug spray. A creek runs adjacent to the trail the whole way, so bringing a dog would be ok. As you get closer to the falls, a bit of scrambling is necessary, but not very difficult. Good boots are helpful, but I honestly could have done this trail in Chaco’s. I got to the falls right at 0830, took a few photos and cooled off. Once I got out of the canyon, the sun was up and direct. I was glad I brought water. Returned to my vehicle at 0930 with a temperature of 72 degrees F. Overall, this is a great and convenient hike. The falls are worth the work and a great place to cool off, although they are surrounded by rock walls, so go early when not many people are there yet. Had the falls to myself.

The Sandy switch backs kinda kicks your butt in the beginning and right before the waterfall you are hugging the rocks and that’s a little bit sketchy for a newbie. It’s all about foot placement. If I can do it anyone can do it!

Was a good trail!  Took our dog and made it up and back in about 2 and a half hours.  There’s some spots with some bees over the water that are a little intimidating but made it by them without a problem :).  I would recommend coming around 5 to make it down by 8 at latest for the best weather.  We came at 12 and it was hot for the first part of the trail but there was acid shade throughout the rest.  Our dog loved it :)
Little hard for beginners but nice hike for a nature lovers

The trail is not well marked and difficult to follow in some places.. especially at the top. The trail also becomes fairly technical and rocky. I wouldn’t recommend hiking it by yourself.. too many risks for injury with the rocks and in veering off trail.
I’ve hiked this more times than I can count and it never gets easier. Shout out to the dude who cut his leg up on the way up
My
This is a great hike although very populated. I would suggest going very early on a weekday.
Great trail!  It was way too hot when we started, so I would say start about 5:30 pm giving yourself plenty of time to come back down during daylight.

Nice trail, steep from the start. Or at least I thought it was, but I am a novice hiker. Wasn’t able to finish because there was a swarm in wasp along the path that I didn’t feel comfortable passing. Overall nice waterfall and hike.
What an amazing hike.
love this trail. I lost my keys though, so if anyone finds a key ring on a purple carabiner, please contact me at 310-867-0808. thanks!

this trail was a beautiful, short hike. the first part up the hill on the initial trailhead is quite the leg workout, but once you get up there is an easy hike with great views all around. I highly recommend making it a sunset hike if you can :)

My first hike with this app! The hike was not nearly as easy as I thought it would be, but I enjoyed it. There was climbing of rocks and even a little bit of getting your feet wet in order to get to the final waterfall. It was nice though. Only complaint is that I wish it was marked better... I was by myself and kept getting “lost” (nothing serious... but I veered off the path a few times).

This is a great little trail! The first .5 miles are dusty switchbacks but after that it’s a shaded hike in the trees next to a cooling stream. The bridge over the stream is at 1.5 and then it’s a good climb to the to waterfall at 1.9 miles. I prefer to do this hike in the evening where you can watch an amazing sunset on your way down. Great hike!

Love doing this hike with my dog. The beginning is definitely the hardest part because of switch backs worth minimal shade. Once that part is over the rest is fun and basically all shaded. There is one more part that is rocky at the end to reach the waterfall but overall gorgeous trail.

The waterfall at the end is the BEST. I hiked this trail in 100 degree weather. TAKE WATER. The switchbacks during the first part of the trail are not shaded at all. But... think this is my favorite trail so far. It’s not easy at all, but well worth it.

The end result... beautiful!!! Switchbacks with no shade in the beginning... and moderate my ass lol this had us climbing rocks, using tree roots and luckily people could show us where the trail was because it is not easily marked.... but the end, BEAUTIFUL!!
Biked not hiked. Had a blast

It is a beautiful hike. The waterfall at the end is definitely worth seeing! of note I would not classify this hike as just moderate. The first half of the hike is moderate, but the last half is at least moderate-hard.
Dogs poop everywhere, bugs... not for beginners.
Love the waterfall

Pretty hike once you get past the switch backs and into the trees. It feels like the hard side of moderate. There is a lot of scrambling over rocks and the trail is washed out in some spots. This hike would be so much better if people picked up after their dog's!
Such a great hike..

Definitely one of the best hikes in Utah. Lots of shade after about the first half mile. I did hike with 3 year old daughter and for the most part it wasn't to bad. it rained and made all the rocks super slippery and I had to carry my daughter the last part before the waterfall.  There is like 3 or 4 really steep parts that make it scary if it's wet.
Crowded and lots of people with dogs. Climbed the first several switchbacks with my young kids. I hear further up would have been difficult for young kids. Beautiful view, just short on time.

I was a bit skeptical at first - went about 3pm (which I'd never do again). Not really for beginners! I loved how the river wound to keep you motivated to see the source! The trail would drift away and just when you think you somehow ended up on the wrong trail a gorgeous spot of water pops into the picture to give you a little boost! It is mostly uphill and not much flat relief - bring lots of water!! Go slow if needed!
Downfall - Really other than the heat which was an error on my part, the only downfall was the amount of wasps near the standing/slower moving water! I am actually shocked I didn't get stung! Otherwise keep going to the end it was well worth it!

Went about 7 am on Pioneer Day.  Not too busy when we got there.  Getting busy when we headed back down.  Shaded after you enter the canyon.  Beginning switchbacks and approach are exposed.  I liked the fact that there were some pretty steep parts followed by relatively flat grade sections that seemed to alternate occasionally.  Gave the legs a needed break a couple of times.  Waterfall is awesome. Different than most waterfalls in the area  in that it's kinda wide and doesn't just flow out of a narrow crevice like most around here.  Good change of pace.  There are a few sections where you choose between rock hopping in the creek or scrambling a steep bank.  Maybe I just didn't look around enough for other options?  Personally I prefer it to Waterfall Canyon in Ogden. I will definitely do it again. I think it was about 1 hour 30 minutes round trip with about 10 minutes spent at the waterfall.

Great trail but not easy for beginners or out of shape people. Switchbacks don't have shade and are Sandy and sometimes washed out. At the trailhead with two arrows go to the right to head toward the falls. Walking sticks would also come in handy as it gets steep. Coming down can sometimes be more difficult than going up but the reward was worth it.

If you’re tip top shape hiker junkie this hike is moderate but if you’re an average joe just wanting to see a waterfall the hike is pretty hard. Lots of steep rocky parts that get you out of breathe but very shaded and lovely on a hot day. Waterfall is beautiful and a nice refreshment after the tiring hike. Also there and back is 5 miles so just be aware of that. But 10/10 would recommend.

Great hike. Try to go early, the switchbacks don’t have shade. Once in the canyon and under the bushes and trees it’s really nice.  Lots of wasps near the standing water along the trail.  Coming down the switchbacks the sand was too hot for my dogs feet. Ended up having to run down to get him in shade.

My sister and I hiked this trail this past Saturday. We started around 8:00 a.m., and completed it at approximately 10:30 a.m. The weather was absolutely perfect. We did encounter plenty of people and dogs on the trail, but everyone was very friendly. The scenery is utterly amazing from start-to-finish. Thankfully we did not encounter hordes of bugs or dog crap on the trail. Overall, a terrific experience.

The perfect moderate trail, just get through those first few switch backs and you’ll be in the nature you know and love. I did this in the afternoon, so after making it to the waterfall the mist and breeze were a nice treat Ü

Decent trail. Lots of traffic though. Lots of families with little kids and dogs. I usually have to add at least 30 minutes to my time because of all the traffic. Early in the morning (6am) or later evening is best. Encounter several snakes about two days ago so keep an eye and ear out for them. Also be careful with all the horse and dog poop.
first part is exposed switchbacks.  but then it's covered and follows river

Great trail, unfortunately there is dog crap all over the first part with the switchbacks and it stinks horribly.  
The upper and lower falls are both great, but people leave trash EVERYWHERE.  My wife and I always take a bag and pick up everyone else's trash because we live close and like to hike here!  Please always pack it out!  If you take children, watch them and pick up after them, this is here to be enjoyed by everyone.
Beautiful hike.  We went on a Monday night and there was very little traffic.

The switchbacks are dusty and can be hot in the afternoon. 

Bring water shoes during the runoff. This will  get you across the water at the end. 

Don't try to wear water shoes the whole way unless you can run through a Japanese game show with them. the sporadic bouldering and sidehilling on this hike is no joke at times.

My Daughter (17) did it with a  broken collar bone no splint fell and tweaked her into bawling only once.

Also as stated previous, bring a trash bag and pack out more than you bring. The "entitled lot" have been here in force.

The first portion is sandy trails which are more recently washed out.  I have passed many people going up and back who inquire if it lasts the whole way.  It doesn't.  Once past the steep sandy first portion the trail grows more and more enjoyable with icy water to play in further up, and shade.  Love this trail.  The trail has gotten more and more crowded on weekends, and recently there are vendors setting up and selling snowcones/food at the entrance so more commercial, but it is still really enjoyable.
The waterfall was beautiful. BUT Seriously people, CLEAN up your dog sh*t. It was honestly disgusting this whole hike smelled nasty... Clean it up and take out or put a ban on the dogs in my opinion.

Unbelievable in so many ways -

The trail is really cool after the initial sandy switchbacks. 

The falls are unbelievably beautiful.  

So is the amount of dog sh** on the trail and the hikers who can’t pick it up. 

And the people who blast their music on the trail.  Most of us get out and hike to get away from that.  

And the people who have their headphones in and can’t hear you when asking permission to pass.  

And all the garbage at the falls - the apples tucked in the bushes, the gummy bears all over the trail, the crackers and the sandwich bags - WTH????  How hard is it to pick up after yourself?

Mother Nature would be ashamed of y’all. 

Glad I did it but won’t be back.  Good luck to the rest of you who choose to hike here.  If it’s serenity and escape from the daily grind, look elsewhere.
Nice trail with a little scrambling. Great falls.
A lot of traffic. Go early or late evening to avoid the traffic.
We loved this trail!! It was beautiful and very fun to hike!

Did this hike Sunday with friends and two 6 year old boys. The boys did great and loved the rock climbing. Some steeper areas and had to walk through the river at the top as the water level is high. Waterfall at the end is totally worth it. Was crowded at the top but to be expected on a nice Sunday afternoon. Took us nearly 3 hours total.
Awesome for kids. A couple of steep areas
Definitely a favorite.
Shady and gorgeous views, love the stream that runs along the trail

Pretty stern test.  If you have real small children or are not in pretty good physical condition I would not recommend.  Some dicey spots that require your undivided attention.  I would take a minimum of 32 oz of water.
Great trail... had some difficult parts but the waterfall at the end made it worth it...
Did a family day trip up with 5 kids (9-15) and made it to the falls.  Nice easy hike with beautiful view at the falls. The bottom has really been groomed up from years back.
super fun trail

This was my very first hike in Utah so I was still acclimating to the elevation and getting in shape. The first part of the trail was brutal because it consists of very steep switchbacks and no shade. It gets much better once you reach the shaded forest. I took off one star for the dangerous scrambling over the eroded steep bank towards the end to get to the falls because the water was raging and you can't climb up the river bed (you could probably do so during a dry year). I honestly did not feel safe doing it and my partner had to talk me through a couple scary spots. Be prepared to get your feet wet since you need to do the river crossing to actually see the falls.

Beautiful hike, went at 5:30pm, took our time then hiked back out watching the sun set over Salt Lake. Stunning all around. However if you’re planning to get to the top, this should be considered a “hard” hike currently with how washed out it is. In a couple areas you have to go through the water and in a couple cases you have to climb over an eroded steep bank. Once at the top you have to cross a powerful current of at least a foot deep to get to the other side to see the waterfall. This trail made me realize how worn the tread is on my boots and how they are no longer waterproof!

Adventurous hike!  The trail starts out on soft sandy ground as you do several switchbacks with a continual incline to the top.  The trail is really rocky with some fun gnarly  sections.  Unfortunately the falls can't be seen right now unless you're prepared to cross the river.  If we had  known we would have brought water shoes.  There are still other awesome things to see along the way though!

This trail was awesome!! It was about 4.25 miles and was washed out in multiple spots, so the terrain was rather rocky! I took my dog along with me, and he loved it! At the mouth of the waterfall, there are strong currents. If you bring small children, or dogs, make sure you’re able to carry them through said currents where you can view the falls (many people were seen doing this, as well as myself), so bring water shoes!!!
Great trail! Mostly shady with a large stream for a majority of the hike. Beautiful waterfall at the end. Very crowded though, but worth it. Will definitely go again.

A gorgeous hike, but not currently safe for toddlers and little kids. the trail is so washed out in places that you have to go through the water or scramble over eroded banks--not something you want to do with a three year old. And it's too popular.
Very crowded. Lots of kids and dogs. Too much scrambling for young kids. Can’t see the falls without getting wet.
Always an enjoyable hike. Above the bridge crossing the hill side has washed out in couple of places and eliminated the trail. Still accessible with scrambling across rocks.
The beginning and ending of the trail are the steepest. there are several washed out spots which require travelling the stream.
One of my favorite hikes. Unfortunately, it has become extremely popular and weekends and holidays are a joke.

I absolutely love this trail. Been on it a few times. The waterfall at the end is gorgeous! But ..... when we hiked this a few days ago, we did encounter an angry rattlesnake. So that wasnt very fun (actually pretty freaky). But still a great hike.

The hike was good! I wouldn’t say it’s moderate. Especially how the trail is washed out. There is quite a lot of dog poop in the beginning during the steep switchbacks. But other than that. The hike has such beautiful views! You do have to cross the freezing cold water in order to see the waterfall!

Lots of traffic, especially on weekends and holidays.  Some of it is in the sun, so start early. I’m a little surprised this is ‘moderate’. This is pretty steep with some scrambles and rocky climbs; and you cross a wide, rocky stream at the top to view the waterfall. late fall through early spring you should have yaktrax or spikes because it gets icy. The waterfall is pretty nice! Also, as of early June 2019 the stream is running high and fast and there are Point where it is very difficult to avoid walking in the water.
The trail is washed out some but that made if fun for us! I would recommend bringing water shoes or a change of shoes or walk to the falls themselves barefoot.
After the switchbacks everything is just beautiful. Great hike for a beginning hiker who wants a challenge.
May 27, 2019.  Snow still on trail the last 1/4 of the trail to the waterfall but worth it.
fun, good workout. didnt make it all the way to the waterfall. little ones got tired. dog owners, please clean after your dogs. there is a lot of dog poop along the trail. we saw a baby rattlesnake.
only bad part is crossing the freezing river at the end but the view was worth it

Overall a good trail, but it is heavily trafficked. Went on a weekday night and the trail was especially crowded on the way down. There are some sketchy areas with slick rock and also near the top where, if you're not in the water, you're holding onto the side of the mountain. Bring water shoes if you don't want to soak your shoes to see the actual falls.

Great trail, just like everyone has said it's very popular so some parts of the trail can get backed up and a bottleneck happens. We hiked this trail last year in May and it was definitely washed out in places this year. (typically where the bottlenecks where happening.) I'd say it's pretty safe for kids but definitely due to the washed out areas might not be appropriate for younger kids. There is a lot more water running down and over the trail than last year. The falls though is about the same from last year. Overall I'd say that this is a moderate to hard trail depending on fitness level. It's pretty shaded too once you get back into the canyon and passed the switch backs.

beautiful trail, some parts are washed out this year. very heavily trafficked, with people causing bottlenecks where the trail is washed out. our 6 year old did okay, it was too much for the 3 year old. I did love the part through the woods next to the creek.
I think it’s actually closer to 5 miles round trip.  The water was too fast to get to the final waterfall.  Still a fun and hard trail!
Fun trail!

I’ve hiked this several times but today there was no way to hike it without getting wet. The trail is washed out in several places with the creek running right over where the regular trail is. This makes for more rock scrambling than usually. And to see the waterfall at the top, I waded through icy cold water up to my knees. (Usually you can just walk across rocks without getting wet.)  Just be prepared if you hike it in a high water spring. I wished I had brought poles to steady myself on the wet rocks too. On a side note, I love this hike in the winter when the waterfall is frozen. Just be sure to wear spikes.
This trail is a favorite of mine only for the fact that it is close. The switch backs are rough but once you get through that part it is absolutely beautiful.

beautiful trail the entire way. i just hiked to the falls today and there were quite a few spots where the trail was washed out. the falls itself right now is crazy, not like pictured here. there's a lot of water flowing right now. the bridge was partially under water on the way back but still passable.

Fun hike. Beautiful trail!  Very crowded though!  Due to some creek crossings - one was pretty deep in swift water, as well at the sloping and slick terrain, it's probably not the best hike for small children.

Beautiful hike. Because I'm a novice it took me two hours to get to the big waterfall and 1.5 hrs back down but well worth it. You will get wet since you have to go in the river a couple of times and at the top you have to completely cross the river to get to see the waterfall. Temperature just right with lots of shade. There are a lot of rocky hills, slippery in some spots.  At the Y in the path before you get to trees keep to the left to continue to the big waterfall.
We only went to the lower falls. We had it all to ourselves for 20 minutes. Kids loved walking through the cold water. It’s and easy 1 mile each way to the lower fall
was way fun, took us about 2 1/2 hours, prepare to get wet feet

As beautiful as ever! With it being such a wet spring the river is really high right now making the current pretty strong and you do have to cross it at the very end of the hike to see the waterfall so that’s something to remember before you start out. I wouldn’t have younger children cross this time of year. Such a fun hike!
I really enjoyed this hike, there are a lot of flat spots between the incline so it’s definitely not steep all the way up. Make sure to check out the lower Falls too.
Water is high in spring, but still manageable if you don't mind getting wet.
Lot of water at the top today.
Great trail, beautiful waterfalls. The water is high and some dogs and small children were having a difficult time crossing the river. Be careful.
Little bit washed out in places so get ready to get your feet wet but other then that I️t was great and the waterfalls were raging

Couldn’t see the waterfall at first because the water level was so high. If you are feeling adventurous, you can climb the rocks without getting your feet too wet and get a great view. Loved the varying terrain!
It is a nice trail for about 3/4ths of the way. You will get to a point where you have to climb or go up and around. I highly reccomend going later in the season if you want to see the waterfall.

Hard to do with children but doable. I just want to encourage people to go all the way and not just to the lower falls because I've encountered so many people who gave up at the lower falls yet they're maybe a couple minutes at most away from the grand spout.
super busy. people. dogs. bikes. horses. full parking almost all the time. very easy hike.
Very dynamic hike. Lots of rocks and intertwining with a stream. Super fun took my dogs. At points need to use hands and it feels like bouldering!

What a great hike. A lot of people but everyone was very friendly. Warning, if you don’t want wet feet don’t do this hike. The water felt great after a quick hike up. There are some tricky spots along the way and I highly recommend hiking shoes for the grip alone. A lot of dogs and families along the way and everyone seems to make it no problem to the top.

This is our second time hiking this trail, first time though was in July of last year so it was much different. This fine area there were some harder areas and areas where you had no choice but to trek through the water. My 5 year old and two dogs were able to make it to the falls though. Still a great hike
Great, quick hike!  Barely any people on the way up early AM on a Saturday.   Expect more people later in the day as we move into summer!
Good quick hike!  Empty on the way up early AM on Saturday, expect lots of people later in the day as we get closer into summer

Awesome cascading water falls and large 25' tall falls at very top of trail. Moderate inclines with switchbacks first 1/2 mile until entering forest canopy. Follows creek the entire route. Moderately difficult through last 1/4 mile, especially with high water. Beautiful trail. Worth the effort. Heavily used. Passed 25-30 people on a Thursday early afternoon.

Very beautiful hike. I’d say it’s moderate- moderate/hard. People went all the way to the waterfall but we didn’t because there way a slushy snow spot that looked a little slippery.. we were carrying our one year old so we just turned back. The whole hike follows a beautiful river! It’s an incline almost the whole way. Watch your footing on some parts!

I’ve hiked this trail many times. It’s a great hike close to town. The trail is easy to follow and surprisingly dry most of the way. There is a little snow slide about 3/4 of the way up that you will have to navigate. It can be a little sketchy as it is slippery. Other than that, you can make it almost all the way to the waterfall with dry shoes. The last 50 feet you will probably get wet. There was a few older couples that made it up today. I don’t know how they navigated that slippery section, but I would say give it a few more weeks before you bring kids under 10.

Pretty much incline from the time you step on the trail. Steep and rocky in some spots. Nice to get into the trees and close to the creek. I wouldn’t recommend for small children. I’d do this one again!

I hiked it and it was incredible, however I saw several mountain bikers.  I have hiked this trail a dozen times and never seen a biker.  There were lots of pups on the trail.  The water was rushing water from the snow melt.  Amazing but scary in a few spots.

Adams canyon trail report:
Trail is dry at lower elevations trail washes out in a few places with large amounts of runoff water! A few difficult sections of snow and wet muddy trails at upper elevations. Use extreme caution and be responsible if your taking family and friends.
This trail has great views and is really well kept.  I saw a lot of mountain bikers riding this trail as well.

I’m new to the area and found the trail by complete accident so I wasn’t prepared for such a hike. The trail starts out very well groomed but it eventually becomes more rugged and slippery. That said, this was a fantastic little hike. Absolutely gorgeous views.

Small patch of slippery snow/ice near the top, but path is otherwise clear.

Recommend wearing Chacos/Tevas or some other water shoes as the river level is high enough to require walking in the water in several spots.

Awesome trail! Overall very easily maneuverable. Lots of snow up near the top of the trail along with the need to walk through the water to see the top of the falls. My suggestion: wear some merrels or chacos and be ready for some cold feet!! Totally worth it though. Our dogs LOVED it!! ❤️
Fun trail lots of shade gorgeous scenery went with seven kids and for adults was a fairly moderate trail some of the water was on the trail but still able to get around just fine

Nice moderate level trail. took 1.5 hours up and 45 minutes down. Still snow packed in the middle half- I had microspiked which I recommend. Other people were doing it without but pretty risky. You have to walk through the creek in parts and to see the final water fall.
very awsome! icy at the top.
Beautiful hike! Still a little snow towards the top, but so worth the hike. Loved the views the whole way!
Loved this trail! Towards the top it does get icy, but it’s pretty easy to get around on the ground off to the side. Very beautiful!

Took the kids for a quick, spring break hike.  Still quite a bit of snow, however we made it all the way to the waterfall. Pretty treacherous for the two teens who said all they needed were tennis shoes
Such a fun and beautiful hike, however there is still a lot of snow and ice at the top.

The hike up is a series of switchbacks and steep enough that these Florida hikers were out of breath pretty quickly. how about we took our time and enjoy the view. There is a lot of traffic noise as you go up.

at the top there is a marker but it mentions nothing about Adams Falls. we went to the right and it appears we made the right choice. went down into a canyon and it became peaceful and quiet with the sound of rushing water.

There was still quite a bit of ice and so we were unable to make it to the waterfall. we stopped at the bridge and enjoyed the water and then hiked back.

At the marker we tried the other side and that basically took us along a ridge that overlooks the city. We didn't take that very far before we turned back.

Overall it was a nice outing and would be a good place to try again when the ice melts.

There was quite a bit of snow on the ground when I did this hike and it was snowing as we went. The snow made the hike even more beautiful! The trail was already packed down from hikers before us! There were some steep parts which the snow made challenging but the waterfall at the top was totally worth it! By far my favorite hike in the area so far!

I would like to rate this somewhere between easy to moderate.I recommend to bring poles or crampons as there are many icy spots as we go up in the mountains. I saw many people sliding down. Overall it was great experience for me and would like to do this again in spring or summer.
A beautiful canyon. Highly recommend this hike. I would rate this hike closer to hard. Maybe I was just having a hard day but it is pretty steep.

One of my favorite trails when I visit Hill AFB. Mainly because it's an excellent after work hike in the Sping. Today was great with 3 inches of fresh snow (trail was already packed down from other hikers by noon) and icicles on the waterfall. Crampons a must.
This is one of my favorite hiking destinations.. the view is absolutely amazing. Great family adventure!!
Took about 2 hours. Microspikes are a must right now! Some of it is even a bit slippery/difficult with spikes on. Keep an eye out of the way up for other frozen waterfalls.

Great hike today. MicroSpikes absolutely necessary,  snowshoes not needed. Trail was packed down nicely.  Took 1 hr to reach waterfall which was running pretty well. Overall great hike today, not too many people.

Great day hike trail in the winter. Lots of cute pups along the way and a great payoff at the end. A bit slippery coming back - Would rec bringing spikes, yak trax, poles or snow shoes if you have them. Still doable if you don’t!
Nothing short of amazing. I have done this hike four times this year but the winter brings a whole new beauty to this hike. Waterfall is mostly frozen. Beautiful take your camera.
One of my favorite trails I’ve ever hiked!! Love the river that’s right next to you and the scenery is amazing!! Definitely a must do!!

Beautiful hike at the end of November (11/30/18). Heavy snow kept us from attempting the last quarter mile but I was playing it safe with my girlfriend. It's doable but slick. Really enjoyed the canopied hiking and rushing creek.

absolutely gorgeous. after a set of switch backs, you follow a stream all the way up to the falls which offers a nice tranquil sound for the entire hike.  You also see some amazing views of the mountains throughout. The hike is fairly challenging in a few places! younger children probably wouldn't be the best to bring here, but older kids would be okay. One of the best hikes I've done!
Amazing views all the way up. Missed peak fall by a week. Trail wasn’t marked very well but it looked like all variations lead to the same point. Phone was at 1% couldn’t record down.

My favorite trail so far for Autumn colors, I went with my friend on Sunday. Very friendly trail as well enjoyed seeing everyone out with their dogs and children. Everyone greeted one another and said good morning.
Beautiful creekside trail especially in the fall. It is moderately challenging if you are not in shape. I personally love this hike and repeat it quite often.
Amazing views and the fall colors were breathtaking. We had an amazing day.

We went to perfect timing with fall leaves and weather. At the top (waterfall) , it can get cold so we were glad we had a good jacket (next time I will bring gloves for my kids hand). Good thing we had a friend who knew exactly where to find the location, it can get little tricky off HWY 89.  We started to hike around 3:30pm and were able to catch the sunset by 7pm. It is dog friendly but little kids may need help to go all the way. Even if you don’t go all the way, it is fun to bring family there. I was told every season this hike is different. Probably not in mid summer where it can get really hot (unless hiking in the early morning). Can’t wait to return back again.
Beautiful Fall hike. Loved the parts along the creek.
Bring a change of socks if you don't want squish foot. This is worth the climb.
Wonderful hike. A little technical in some places.

amazing trail if you need something to kick your butt. the first little section is a bit awful just because of the dust and switchbacks but once you're past those, it's all beautiful and shady! dogs are free to roam off the leash and mine loves all the water along the way.
its uphill the whole way good times beautiful waterfall. beginners were at that are we there yet about 3/4 way. lolz. so worth it. well worn trail.

Lovely hike to a beautiful waterfall. i enjoyed hiking by the stream and seeing all the beautiful little cascades of water and mini waterfalls.  We started early but I can imagine when it is hot the first part would be a beast! The information we read said dogs were welcome if on a leash...I saw lots of dogs and none of them were on a leash!  The dog poop along the trail left by inconsiderate dog owners was a real distraction to this beautiful trail!  Come on dog owners pick up after your dogs or don't use this trail!
Great hike to a beautiful waterfall.
Great hike / trail run. 3.9 miles from the Parking lot, 1.5 hours. Good workout

There are three parts to this hike.
Part 1: Walking up switchbacks on sand (!) with a city view behind you (also Bonneville Shoreline Trail)
Part 2: Very nice hike along Adams Creek in shade on dirt-and-rock path
Part 3: Do-able scramble up large rocks

It is about 2 miles from the parking lot to the falls and took 1 hour. (We are average 20-something Utah transplants and it was a lovely fall morning.) So in total, about 4 miles or 2-2.5 hours. It is incline the whole way in and decline the whole way out.

The reviews here that say 3.4 miles total I believe stopped at the first little waterfall that kind of runs through a couple large boulders. When we got to that, my watch said exactly 1.7 mi. — The others that include pictures at the base of an actual waterfall did the 1/2 mile or so large rock scramble that comes after that initial falls.

Our dog loved this trail. Going in the morning was awesome because it was the perfect temperature before it started getting hot, and the trail was noticeably busier on the way back. Everyone on the trail was super courteous and friendly.

The parking lot is really uneven and rocky, but was very nice to have and more than enough space for the 8am to 10am crowd.
Pretty steep the way up.  Gets to a tree line and then all shade walking by the river.  Keep winding up to a horseshoe turn right eventually and you’ll find the waterfall.
Great out and back hike. Falls at top are beautiful.

This is one of THE best hikes I have been on. The scenery is amazing. A beautiful running creek flows alongside most of the trail. The reward of this hike only gets better as you reach the breath taking waterfall at the top.

My first hike in Utah! Definitely was a little bummed at first with the dust and switchbacks but after that it's beautiful! Shady and nice scenery. Get diversity of rocks and dirt trails and the waterfall at the end was pretty. Plenty of places to stop for a sip of water for both me and my pup!
Great trail. Some steep parts but very scenic and full of nice people.

This was a fun trail. I would recommend shoes with plenty of grip. There are plenty sections of the trail where it's loose dirt and it's easy to lose your footing. Moderate is a good rating. The trail has plenty of areas that will elevate your heartrate!

This was a very enjoyable hike. Not the best for the first half a mile but after that you follow the river most of the way and there are 4 water falls on this trail with the last one being the best. I'm ready to do this one again. one of my favorites.

great place to hike. many dogs off leash and very cool people. river runs along with trail for a lot of the hike and some great shade once you get into the trees. Beautiful and a lot of fun. My dog Shenzi had a wonderful time and I got a great work out. I would recommend it to anyone!!!

This trail is really pretty; the first 1/2 mile is hot, but once you hit the shade, it is rather pleasant.  The hike along the creek is cool with plenty of opportunities to cool off if you choose.  The final 1/2 mile to the waterfall is a little steep, but it is completely worth it in the end.  The trail is heavily trafficked, so if you are looking for seclusion, this is not the place.
Had a great hike. Gets a little step and rocky before the waterfall.  It's quite refreshing once you get there. My 6 year old was able to make it.

First part of trail .5 miles is all sun and you feel like your in the desert.  Then it turns along the river and all shade.  Nice to follow river up to waterfalls.   Waterfall is nice and you can splash around before heading down.
Oldie but goodie. Not too difficult for the most part. The last half mile or so may be a little challenging for kids.

This is my son's favorite trail.  We have to do it every year.  I have to admit with the heat I was not looking forward to it.  Leaving later in the day was really pretty nice.  The creek kept the heat down and the traffic was not too bad.  Watched a great sunset on the way down.

This a beautiful hike but I am 60 and in pretty good condition and I would call this hike hard.  There were lots of young people but not a lot of older adults (senior).  As you get to the top you are climbing through the rocks at a fairly steep incline.  That being said the payoff at the end, the falls, are amazing.  It was worth the climb definitely.
Beautiful
Great hike, shady most of the way. Really fun waterfall at the end that makes it all worth it!

I absolutely love this trail! It is a beautiful scenic hike with some challenging parts. The switchbacks are rough in the beginning since it is a steep incline. After that, make sure to go right when the trail splits, and then stick left close to the mountain all the way up to the waterfalls. There is a small waterfall before the large one. It is only about an extra ten minutes to the large waterfall once you hit the small waterfall. There are steep parts on the trail and toward the waterfall, I was almost rock climbing. The hike was challenging but very fun! There is always a place to stop and rest, too. I love hiking up along the side of the stream. Getting to the final waterfall was definitely worth it!
love this trail.  tried it as a beginner and made it to the top.  now I come a few times a year.  my kids love splashing in the water up at the waterfall

This trail is rated moderate but there are parts that are hard! The switchbacks at the beginning of the trail are tough because it is a steady incline and sandy. Once you get closer to the waterfall, there are some very steep parts that are borderline rock climbing/bouldering. With that being said, it was a fun and challenging trail.
Worth it to make it to the top! I’m an “older” hiker so I had to rest quite a bit but there was always a beautiful spot to sit.

Me and my wife finally made it to the top waterfall.  The last few times we’ve tried she was 7 1/2 months prego and the next was with a 7 month old or so.  We left the kids home this time and got to the top. Awesome hike. I just wish people would pick up dog poop!!!!  If you have a dog pick up after it.....at least get the crap off the trail.
Awesome
Great hike! Took my 12 year old and was very glad my 4 year old  wasn’t  with me. Is such a great hike along the river up to the waterfall. Some tough incline spots, but very well worth it!!
The valleys and wildflowers are spectacular in spring. The uphill was in sections so not too much to take on.

Beautiful hike. I went on my own in the morning. I saw a few people on the trail, it was a Tuesday morning. Coming up I came upon people trail running down. Go in the morning because the first part of the trail is completely exposed.

This was a great hike! I have done lower falls about 25 times with my kids, but never without them. I finally had a chance without kids to do this.  We started on the trailhead around 7:25 ish, and finished at 10pm.  It was 1.97 Miles to the waterfall, and ended up being a little less than 4 Miles total.  The 3.4 Miles is deceiving, and once you hit 1.7 Miles the rest of the way to the waterfall is difficult and the path isn’t clear.  It got dark before we got out of the canyon and n d d the help of a flashlight to see the rocks and path.

If you haven’t done it, do it! The waterfall is stunning and worth it.  This hike is equivalent to waterfall canyon trail in my opinion.  My kids (4 & 1) did waterfall canyon last year and it took 6 hours, I don’t think I will take them on this hike for another year.

We hiked this trail all the way up to the waterfall last Sunday with our two dogs and 4 year old son. The first part with the switchbacks is just sand and not covered at all so our dogs definitely struggled through that on the way up and back. Once you drop into the canyon it is covered for the most part with fairly easy access to the water where our dogs cooled off. There are some areas that made us a little nervous with tow dogs and a child but everyone did great. We clocked it at right around 6 miles up and back, but we also took a wrong turn on the way back down. The waterfall was beautiful and our son had a blast playing in the water at the top. I would definitely say take snacks or a lunch and enjoy the waterfall while you rest. Also take water! We thought we had enough and definitely could have used more. We did encounter areas that had a substantial amount of wasps but walking right through them was no problem and they didn’t bother us. Also saw one rattle snake on the way up but he was off to the side and moving away from us with no issues.

I’ve done this hike several times and love it. Went today and there were quite a bit of wasps throughout the trail. Thought I’d leave a review for people who may have kids that are easily spooked. However, from my experience this is not the norm.
nice hike not to long not to short.

First part is straight up a sandy path, which has little cover on a hot sunny day. Once you enter the trees, majority of hike is covered minus a few spots. Fairly difficult second half with rocks and incline, depending on your fitness level. We went late in day and other reviews are accurate, fairly crowded. Top is a nice waterfall with some areas to sit. Also areas throughout trail to sit and rest. Saw quite a few families with young children doing the hike, as well as dogs.
Very nice hike to a beautiful waterfall but too many people

I love this hike with my whole heart! It’s kinda hard but absolutely WORTH IT! The waterfall is beautiful and the views are spectacular all along the way (once you get past the sandy switchbacks, of course) hIGHLY recommend. I went on a Tuesday afternoon and there was not that many people to pass, and no bikes passing either which is nice :)
Steep and Sandy switchbacks at the start of the trail, but once you're back into the trees this hike has some great sights.
awesome hike! plenty of shade and Beautiful scenery!!

I did this hike on Saturday (06/30). I was the hot guy I the blue shirt that said, "Virginia is for Lovers".

Great vibes on this trail. There's a good amount of ups and downs on this trail. Never give up, never surrender.
Pretty hike once you get passed the switch backs, downside is it’s always pretty crowded!

The first 1/2 mile or so of the hike is just switchbacks in the direct sunlight, with sand under your feet. Once you hit the canyon, the hike is gorgeous! Lots of shade. Small elevation gain, so most people should be comfortable with this trail, if you’ve been on a few hikes already. There were plenty of families and kids on this trail, but it wasn’t overly busy. The waterfall at the end is very rewarding. I climbed all the way up and around, so I could stand at the top of the waterfall, right at the edge and look directly down it. So cool! It was a slight technical climb, so I doubt most people will do this. However, if you have any rock climbing experience, or are somewhat athletic, I recommend it. At the edge of the waterfall there are straps anchored into the rock, so you could rappel down if you brought a rope. Unfortunately I didn’t know it was there, so didn’t have my rope with me. We tried throwing a small one up to me, but it failed. So I climbed back down without rappelling down the waterfall. Though, I will be back later this summer to rappel down. Anyway, highly recommend this hike to anyone!
A lot of climbing but plenty of shade. It was a fun trail.
fun trail and shaded, pretty waterfall
Its a great trail. The end is very rewarding and nice to see.

Went on 6-23-18 at 6:30am and there was hardly anyone there. It is a moderate to hard hike with all the inclines. Waterfall and hike are absolutely gorgeous with lots of shade. Brought my dog and she loved it. We passed about 30-45 people on the way back. I’d highly recommend going as early as possible to miss the rush.
I love this trail, it was very fun and adventures throughout. me and my partner made it to the end where there is a very beautiful waterfall at the end much rewarding.  my first this year 2018.
Great little hicking trail. very rocky by my 4 kids made it just fine ages 8, 6, 4 and 2 in a baby backpack.

This is a great hike if you want a quick escape.  However, there are a lot of people, so be prepared for that. I've gone in the early spring before and that was kind of fun... made it a little more exciting with the ice and mud :)

Beautiful hike, totally worth it. I got 4.5 miles total though on my Apple Watch and on the recording from this app so it’s more than what it says. It’s wasn’t bad at all after you got past the first part. There is dog poop because apparently people can’t pickup after their dogs, but it was still worth it!
I tripped down this hike about 8 times, but other than that beautiful hike!

great hike and waterfall is nice at the end, lots of cool spots to climb rocks and get better views of the waterfall or scenic forest tops if you like to free climb. Annoying part is people leave there dog poop everywhere, and when they do use a doggie poop bag, they just leave the poop there on the ground in the bag. Some pretty inconsiderate people thats for sure.
Great hike nothing to complain about on the trail. Always nice to get to the shaded area and the waterfall is still awesome
I have not made it to the waterfall yet but love this trail.  If you’re new to hiking at this altitude I would take it easy at the beginning during the switchbacks.

This trail was awesome!! It was also 3.0+ mi up and 3.0+ miles back. This trail is 6 miles long to reach the big waterfall with ~1,700 elevation gain (according to strava). The trail is not well shaded for the first 1 mi, and it’s all uphill. Once you hit the stream it’s mostly shaded. Bring an extra jacket, water proof/resistant once you reach the top. The trail is also more moderate/hard once you hit the bigger stream/falls (~last 1.5 mi up), so no strollers. It is a difficult climb up for the last 1 mi, and not great for people who are clumsy, not paying attention, or those who are used to lower elevations. Overall- dog friendly, moderate/hard, wear good hiking shoes that you can get wet. We brought a 9 and 6 year old and they were struggling to hike uphill so much, on uneven terrain. Remember *yield to uphill traffic *. Thanks for reading!!

Love this trail! It’s a popular one, and really beautiful. I would recommend hiking it in the morning, because even on a cool day you’ll break a pretty good sweat. My only complaint is that because it’s well populated, there is a decent amount of litter along the trail (as well as dog poop). Come on people, how hard is it to clean up after yourself?
The trail is very rocky and steep in places. There are lots of shaded places to take a break. Give yourself plenty of time, the waterfall at the end is amazing.

Wow those switchbacks at the beginning are rough. I don’t usually have my asthma triggered from hiking, but I had to use my inhaler 3 times before getting to the top. Once we were on the trail it was pretty clear where to go. Kids and dogs did okay, but there are a lot of steep spots and rocks to climb. Didn’t make it all the way to the waterfall, but it was still fun.
Nice pretty hike real rocky at top pretty water fall watch out for rattlesnake I all most ran into one

Great hike!  Was able to easily do with my 9 year old.  Exposed to the sun in the switchbacks but shaded once you reach the canyon.  Several spots to cool down in the creek too.

The only complaint was a minority of dog owners who were irresponsible in not picking up after their pets.  This is a very busy trail, requiring everybody to do their part in keeping it clean for those that follow.
Fun trail! it does get steep and kind hard at the top. Bring good shoes because you will need to climb rocks and boulders. I brought my dog and he had a great time.
Took dog, very much moderate but plenty of break spots along the way to a nice waterfall. Lots of rocky spots, wear good shoes and take it slow (some were loose).

One of my favorites because it gives you a huge varieties of challenges.  Towards the waterfall you will encounter a little rock scaling but nothing to severe.  
Weekends tend to be a little crowded but most hikers are courteous and will give way.  Lots of puppies including mine will be out on the trail.  

Happy Trails...

Our family of five really enjoyed our first hike in Northern Utah today! We took the trail to the right to check out the Lower Canyon waterfall and really enjoyed playing around the falls. It took us about an hour round trip, and was the perfect way to spend a morning!

We loved this trail! For a family with young children, it was perfect. A great length and challenge. The switchbacks were steep, but not too difficult. Above the switchbacks, we took the trail to the right and went to the lower falls. There was one area where it was tricky getting our four- and two-year-old down, but our five-year-old was  a champ. It was really pretty along the whole trail, great views of the city, horizon, and mountains.

This is a beautiful hike, but not as pretty as it used to be. The popularity of this trail shows in the amount of litter up this canyon. Graffiti in the form of carving trees, logs and scrawling on rock faces also seems on the rise. I hike this canyon weekly so perhaps I notice it more than others.

Aside from the litter and graffiti, this canyon is beautiful! The trail is well maintained although rocky and runs right next to the river for the majority of the hike. It is also fairly shaded making late morning and early afternoon hikes fairly comfortable. Plan on 45-120 minute hike times up to the falls depending on your personal level of fitness. You will encounter other people and many dogs on this trail so not a place of solitude if that is what you seek. If you do take this hike, please take an extra bag and pack some litter out with you on your way down the trail!

Went up about 7pm yesterday (end of May) even after the rain was damp but not so muddy that we slid around or anything. After you get into the shady trees it is quite a bit darker so if you are planning on an evening hike keep in mind it will get dark earlier. Lots of climbing up boulders as part of the trail and once you reach the waterfall, just plan on feet getting wet in the shallow water that you’ll want to walk through. Beautiful views at sunset.
First time going up there today. Very intense! The view is beautiful and the waterfall is worth the ruff terrain. Wear hiking shoes and take snacks.
50 years old and not in shape, but steady persistence makes for a great day with the family!!

Whoa this hike was difficult. Being new to the area and still getting used to the elevation this hike kicked our butt. We made it though! The waterfall was absolutely worth it. Little purple butterflies everywhere it was picturesque. The way there was exhausting a lot of uphill and a couple areas where you climbed over rocks but nothing drastic. The way back was easy we flew back to the parking lot. Just a couple areas on the way down were steep and you had to be careful not to slip which I nearly landed on my back a few times if it weren’t for my skillz. Also when you see the bridge about a quarter of the way on the trail don’t go that way. We did for a while and had to backtrack. Which was dumb cause it should have been common sense to stay near the creek so we ended up on Bonneville which was a nice trail and cacti everywhere.. but yes if you see the bridge don’t continue on that trail. Good spot to take a break though! Bring lots of water!! And a snack/meal to reward yourself when you make it to the falls
Great hike.
Great trail to take the kids and dogs. Get there early!
Beautiful!

The first part of this hike is difficult due to the steep switch backs, then you get into the green and it is beautiful at every turn! It is steep in some areas with lose rocks, so go slow, and coming down was a bit scary. However I was doing this packing my 6 month old, so it’s possible. I’m a moderately in-shape person. Would not recommend this for young kids. It took my friend and I about 2.5 hours out and back while staying at the falls for a while.

Beautiful trail! Lots of trees to shade the trail. The creek runs along the trail the whole way. Great for dogs. The waterfall was the perfect end to this trail. If you want to go to the shoreline trail from there it is not accessible for dogs, it’s a steep rock climb up from the waterfall.
Beautiful scenery! Great hike!
Great hike. Decently difficult, so come prepared. Really pretty views of the valley. Busier than I expected, but not too bad. I'll definitely be going again!
fun hike. longer than anticipated but worth it !
Love this hike.
Great hike, amazing waterfall at the end but my shoes did get wet to see it.
Amazing hike! Beautiful the whole way to the water fall. I would definitely rate it as hard though. A lot of uphill scrambling over rocks and cliff like areas.
So pretty! Go early in the morning on weekday and you’ll have no problems with too many people.
This is a great hike with a gorgeous waterfall! Very popular with hikers.
Great hike.  We got to see an awesome sunset on the way back down.

This trail is amazing- but SO heavily trafficked. There were so many people on the trail- we had to walk single file for so much of it just because we were passing people constantly. There were many dogs off-leash and dog poop everywhere!! In addition there were many mountain bikers tearing around like crazy. I’d go again, but very early on a weekday and without any children.
One of my very favorite hikes!  It was perfect!
grew up hiking this trail it is heavily trafficked now but I still love it !
Loved every minute! Thought I had hiking shoes but slippery going down. Getting hiking shoes and doing it again!! This Texas girl doesn’t have anything like this!! I’ll be back soon!

GO EARLY! 

This trail is absolutely AMAZING...but everyone else thinks so too. We got there on a Saturday morning around 8:30 and there were maybe 30 cars. By the time we left a few hours later there were probably 150! 

This trail starts of with tons of sandy switchbacks and it is challenging. I probably wouldn’t take my 6yo, but it quickly gets shaded and is a real treat the entire way.
Great hike and beautiful waterfall! Only downside was how many people were on the trail.. it was quite crowded.
Convenient hike for Davis County residents. Pretty. Good workout but lots of traffic - go early in the am.

This is one of my favorite hikes. The beginning where the switchbacks are is the hardest part. The hike gets easier after that. I would not recommend bringing upping children. I need one water bottle up and down. It takes about 2-2 1/2 hours to hike. Depending on how long you stay at the waterfall.

One of the best hikes in the Uintah/Weber County area. It's gorgeous once you're past the beginning switchbacks. If you're in good shape, it can be completed in about an hour + or - 30mins. This should not be rated hard. Malans Peak is rated moderate and it is much more strenuous. Great reward at the top. Water proof Hiking shoes to cross the creek is recommended.
Once you get past the sandy switchbacks - it doesn’t get much better than this.
Love this trail pretty heavily trafficked but still beautiful and worth the hike

The switchbacks at the beginning are rough but once you get past them it’s such an amazing hike. There is little to no littering and the streams are nice to cool off and enjoy. Everyone on the trail is always super nice and there are lots of dogs. It’s a really nice hike.

I love this hike. It’s a nice distance for a quick hike and good workout. It’s shaded most of the way which makes this hike enjoyable for any time of day hiking. Hiking in the winter time is super enjoyable as well...climbing poles can be especially useful then can we helpful for occasional icy patches... Still, I go without them usually.

This is my go-to trail for running. Easily accessible and just the right amount of mileage and ascent for an hour run.

The first mile is exposed, don't forget protection and water. Kid and dog friendly so bring the whole family.

The switchbacks are tough, but once they are behind you beautiful canyon scenery with a waterfall at the end are your reward.

After you cross the bridge it's about another half mile climb over a rock field to get to the waterfall. Keep the river on your left and you'll be fine.

Saturday's are incredibly busy, so start early and be ready to face crowds of people. I usually run it on Sunday mornings and there are only a handful of other people.

Used Adam's Canyon Trail to get to Adam's Cabin Trail. Very difficult to get to Cabin Trail from Waterfall (Canyon) Trail. We enjoyed the challenge of it as we found ourselves in the middle of nowhere. Near the cabin the trail is covered by snow but we were able to use a previous hiker's footprints. Definitely will do it again but will use Adam's Cabin Trail. Missed the waterfall due to high water.

Beautiful hike! Some bouldering at the end. Mostly dry. 

Not well marked. Kept getting lost/confused. My advice: follow the stream the entire way. You’ll be on the left for most of it then there’ll be a bridge taking you to the right side somewhere along the way. AllTrails thinks this trail is longer than it actually is. If you keep looking for a trail by the big waterfall, you’re probably not going to find it xD
love this hike! it's never too crowded but expect a few people around between 10-2. it's a nice work out all the way through.
Beautiful views, the waterfall was awesome! Highly recommend this hike.
Great hike. The views are amazing.

My 5 yr old twins and I hiked this trail today and was not disappointed.
They handled the trail great and the waterfall at the end was a great reward.
Beautiful hike and will be returning.
My husband and I loved this hike!  Took our two Chocolate Labradors and they had a blast! Tired dogs for sure!
Awesome hike. My 5yo and 7yo were able to make it all the way to the waterfall. it's a tough hike but worth it. the trail is pretty busy. I think the hardest part of the hike is the very beginning.

It’s a very steady hike at the beginning but by the end it does get a little steeper. The hike is almost completely dry except for a minute at the end where you have to cross water to be able to see the waterfall.
For me the hike was about 5 hours total, with nice areas along the way to take breaks or eat lunch.
Canyon is beautiful. Very little snow, river is easily crossable - great time to be out!
Nice hike. It was crowded for a weekday. Good for families, passed by a lot of kids. Lots of dogs and dog waste along the trail. Couldn’t find a trash to throw away my dogs waste.

2017
Great Hike, First Utah Hike
Bring your ice cleats this time of year...
Great day hike. Dog friendly. it is a steady climb the whole way. Good shoes and plenty of water is a good idea.
Great hike! I didn’t think it was as difficult as it was rated! Nice and dry try most the way up!!
Awesome trail! Lots of different small trails to take around the mountains/falls. If I could give it 6 stars I would!
My absolute favorite trail!
1-11-18 do not even try without spikes! Stop at Gear:30 in Ogden for some spikes!

It's not as hard as they make it out to be once you ascend into the canyon. The waterfall is beautiful and the trail is nice, the only reason I don't rate it 5 stars is for the crowds that are common. Still a favorite
Fun quick trail!
This is a great hike!
my favorite trail ♡
Was a great trail!
Loved it! It’s not as far as it’s posted it’s about 1.6 miles to the waterfall you can go further but it’s rock climbing. So worth it!
Awesome hike, hard at the beginning with the switchbacks but other than that pretty easy.

My dog and I do this trail frequently and I would recommend it to anyone. There are several different ways to get up if you are willing to explore. The sandy switchbacks in the beginning are the roughest part in my opinion. Great Waterfall if you complete the hike.

We're visitors from CA and some friends turned us on to this beautiful river hike. Would have given five stars but found a lot of rubbish, a few carved up trees and the trails were poorly marked if even existent. Pretty sweet waterfall at the top. Fun little hike & will definitely do this hike again next time we visit.
amazing and spectacular right now with fall colors

Pretty easy hike. The worst part is at the beginning with the switchback after switchback but other than that it was a breeze. It some very pretty views as well. It took my friend and me about 1 and a half hours to do round trip
Great trail

Grew up hiking this trail. Love love love it. Not sure why it has a hard rating though. I feel a moderate rating would be appropriate. Plenty of flat spots and moderate inclines. The steepest part is the switchbacks at the beginning (don't attempt in the heat. the sun will beat down on you and you will want to die).
The waterfall is a great reward at the end. There are some stream crossings so depending on the water level your feet might get wet.
Heavily trafficked. Great for families (the first part might tough on really little ones).
We actually just hiked to the lower falls.  After the first set of switchbacks, just take a right after the bench, and follow it down to a gorgeous waterfall.  Great hike for kids!

It is better to hike this trail early in the morning.  It is a difficult hike but well worth it.  There is plenty of shade once you get past the steep switchbacks.  Bring plenty of water and be ready to sweat.  This hike is strenuous at best.  Watch your footing because it's easy to roll an ankle.  If you're looking for amazing scenery and want a great workout, then this trail is for you.
Love this trail

This hike is fun and varied, but takes much longer with small children or older adults. We had a three year old and a 57 year old grandma. It took us 5 hours round trip. Take lots of water and good shoes!
my 2.5 yr old did fantastic on this trail. very beautiful and lots of great views.
Nice hike you think you're physically doing good until you head back down and then you realize how steep this trail really yes but definitely worth the hike absolutely beautiful

Once you get past the switchbacks there is a lot more shade, but I will definitely bring more water next time or start earlier.  We started at 4 and it was way too hot but that was all that worked with all the family.

Great trail!  The sandy switchbacks at the beginning and the steep climbs toward the end make this a challenging trail run.  Watch out for rattlesnakes in the sunny areas in the evenings.  I've seen two this summer.

This is one of my favorite hikes! I love hearing the water flowing in the river throughout the hike and the Beautiful waterfall is fun to get wet in after getting hot and sweaty! Great trail... be sure to wear shoes you can get wet. There are also so great sitting places to eat a snack or lunch.

This is an incredible hike and has huge payoff. If you are doing this in the summer, I would suggest going in the early morning. There is some shade once you are in the canyon, but it can still get toasty.

this hike is a little hard it's got some switchbacks and some rocks you need to climb but if you take it slow the large fall at the top is worth it. there are two Little Falls and a creek that you see on the way up to the top.  it's a busy Trail so if it looks like you're going to get lost lots of people to help you get on the right track

Excellent trail with diverse conditions. It was good for my family to hike up on clear paths and then get into scrambling over rocks the last .5 mikes to the falls. The falls are amazing. Coming back is perfect for a trail run on the downhill. The stream offers a constant and natural AC.

This trail is great for a short hike! Started at 6pm, spent 30 minutes at the waterfall, and got back to the trailhead at sunset (9pm in mid-July). I rated four stars because (a) there were a few unmarked forks in the trail and (b) I slipped on a rock and slid down a rocky slope into the creek. It was more humorous than anything else, but it was inconvenient. Overall tho, this was a really fun hike with a great reward at the end. Also, coming back down, the view of the sunset was spectacular! I would divide this trail into four parts:
1) The trailhead parking lot, a short walk along a chain link fence, and then a lot of sharp switchbacks. This section climbs up the side of the Wasatch Range foothills and provides a nice warmup that mades the rest of the hike seem easier. There's some good views of the Salt Lake Valley along the climb.
2) After reaching the top of the foothills, the trail levels out into a fairly level and grassy stretch. This is were the view of the sunset was. It provides a great vantage point across most of the Salt Lake Valley, as well as a nice rest after the steep switchbacks. This is where the trail merges with the Bonneville Shoreline Trail.
3) The bulk of the hike, after turning off of the Bonneville Shoreline Trail, climbs up thru Adams Canyon. There's not really any views worth mentioning until reaching the waterfall, but the end is worthwhile. As long as you watch your step, you'll be fine. I only slipped because I wasn't paying attention at the moment.
4) The waterfall. It was probably in the best little cove to view it that I could have asked for. The trail comes up from the southwest, you walk across the creek on rocks, and then see the waterfall. It's on the southeast side and falls into a pool that fills most of the cove. Unless you have rockclimbing equipment, the trail ends here; cliffs surround everything. There's a large sandy bar on the north side that you can stand on, and a 10-foot rocky perch on the northwest side, across the creek from where you come up and opposite the waterfall. Climbed it, great view of the waterfall, romantic spot; do it!

Adams Canyon is a great hiking trail for most ability levels. It can be completed from start to finish in about 3 hours tops. Once you get closer to the top though, there are a few climbing obstacles that can get kindof challenging, but not too bad. I have seen quite a few little children on this trail (ages 3-5ish) with their parents, although I would not advise taking your younguns unless they are able to climb fairly well on their own. What's nice about this trail is it's nice no matter what time of day you decide to go. The switchbacks in the beginning can be uncomfortable if it's a hot day, but they only take about 20-30 minutes to get through before you reach the canyon where it's nice and cool, and shaded throughout the remainder of much of the trail. A beautiful waterfall is your reward for reaching the top! Be advised that you WILL need to cross the river in order to actually see the waterfall, so be prepared to get wet. Take a pair of water shoes if you have them so you don't have to take off your shoes, or hike back down in wet socks and boots. Also, I would recommend taking a bottle or two of water as well.
