A little bit harder on the moderate side, the sandy switchbacks at the start are rough, but once you really hit the trail it's a lot better. Great views going in to the canyon the waterfalls are totally worth it.
Awesome
It was a nice trail just supper dusty all in all worth the hike for sure
We took our kids ages 8, 6, 3 & 4 months.  Most of the hike is moderate, but becomes more moderately strenuous towards the end, especially with kids.  We had a great time!
Not to busy in an early Saturday afternoon. Made it up and back in an hour and a half. Did not stop and was going at a fast pace.
Fun trail but it's always way too crowded on the weekends.

Hiked with my four kids, ages 11, 10, 5, and 3. Pretty intense for my three year old but she did it all! Shady and by the river most of the way. Beautiful. Could just do a portion if time/ability don't allow to go all the way to the fall. Took us 3 hours and 45 minutes at a slow three year old pace. Will definitely do again!
It was good. I like any trail with water. Very steep climb all 2 miles up. I would like to hike along the water the whole length next time. Looking forward to winter to snow shoe this one.
This is always a good out and back hike. It is a well traveled trail and there are a lot of dogs. It is very rewarding to play in the waterfall at the end on a hot day.
amazing hiking,with a beautiful view and beautiful water fall.
It was a quick, semi-difficult trail with varying features. The fall was unexpectedly refreshing.
Hike early in the morning. Beautiful waterfall at the top!

great hike, the first 30 minutes is no shade,  so it gets hot really fast, but then you get in the forest and you can refresh yourself by the river while you make it to the waterfall,  it's a 2 hour hike total

It's pretty steep I took an 8 y/o, two 7 y/o, and 1 11 month old child. It was definitely a good workout and the kids loved it. Had some rocky parts so if you take kids just beware of that. Also it  gets confusing when you get to the top and the trail seems to just disappear. You'll cross a bridge in the river and see a big rock wall and you can go up and around it to see the waterfall...or go down and climb up around the rock wall. you'll find a small waterfall once you're around that rock. If you want to see the bigger waterfall then keep hiking for about 10 more minutes.
Switch backs in the beginning are hard but after you are pass that it gets better. Enjoyed the hike!!

This trail is way too over hiked. Very dusty and trampled by hundreds of people each day. It is the most popular hiking trail in all of Davis County. It is extremely convenient and the trail head is easy to find. It offers an awesome workout with a pretty sweet waterfall, but just too congested for me.
Steep in the beginning but overall nice trail. Beautiful at the top. Hiked with my 7 year old.

The switch backs in the beginning are exhausting, but once you get past that, it's a good trail. Unfortunately having my 3 yr old in the backpack carrier, we couldn't get to the waterfall. We will be back!!

I was very impressed by this short trail. Great scenery for a two mile hike. Some switchbacks at the beginning but then you enter the trees shortly after that. We went on July fourth and there were around 150 people on the trail. It really wasn't too crowded, though, but certainly busy. There are several small waterfalls the way up and the one at the top was quite large. There were people repelling just to the right of the falls which was cool. We climbed from the falls up to the peak and that was a somewhat difficult hike/easy climb but the view of the valley was well worth it.

I just went yesterday with some of my boys (11-15) and it was great.  It has a very nice variety. A  little strenuous, a steep climb or two, a few places where you have to be careful., some time in the sun, a few places, where you get your feet wet but mostly shaded.  The water and waterfall were beautiful.  it took us just about three hours (at a good, average pace). I highly recommend it.  Trails is pretty easy to follow, it does intersect with the Bonnevile Shorleline Trail, so don't get diverted.

"Lightly trafficked" is a pretty misleading statement. We hiked this trail during the week and there was still at least 100 people, which is no problem! But when you're looking for a little seclusion...that many people on one trail can be overwhelming. I was very disappointed with the amount of dog feces on the trail as well. The unpleasant smell takes away from the beauty and natural smell of the wild flowers. Aside from that, the scenery was beautiful and the reward of the falls was great.

Fun, challenging trail, some steep switchbacks to begin and then some other steep spots along the way with rocks and boulders to maneuver around. The waterfall is real pretty. Worth the effort to get there.
Nice trail. Hiked it with the family on the 24th of June. There are some switchbacks at the beginning that kind of suck. The waterfall at the end os beautiful.

Made it to the 1.5 mile mark, I will be back.  Saw a baby rattlesnake on the trail at about 6:45pm at the 1 mile mark.  Awesome challenging hill climb to start, and a few good ups thereafter.  Lots of people on a trail for a Tuesday evening.

Loved this hike! I was looking for something slightly longer than I was used to and this was perfect. There were a couple of times where we questioned if we were going the right way, but there were a good deal of people up there so we ended up following people a couple of times. It splits off near the beginning so make sure you go to the left and not down the Bonneville shoreline. You do have to walk through the water to see it, though, so be ready to get your feet wet. I loved the waterfall, though!

First time on the trail today. Started at 9:00 am but should have gone earlier cuz it got hot!  Bring lots of water! First time I've emptied my 2 liter camelback on a hike. Lots of friendly people along the way. I wouldn't recommend for young kids!!  I got lost a few times & had to backtrack. The water was beautiful & refreshing. Your shoes will get wet as you have to cross the creek to see the final beautiful waterfall. Had to hike...crawl...over a few large boulders too. Overall - Beautiful! Challenging! Refreshing

The zig zag up hill in the beginning is a little hard to get up so I like to stair at the ground and push myself to keep going. I know once I'm passed that it gets easier. You fallow the trail to the right side of the mountain. Hikers walk along a running creek through dirt and rocks. Some rocks are obstructing the path and need to climbed over or you can walk in water around them. The hike is mostly up hill. There are a few good spots along the way to rest. I did get lost off the trail towards the waterfall and did some rock climbing but it was really easy. Got right back on the trail. Two waterfalls on this hike actually. One is smaller but not too much before getting to the main waterfall. I loved the views! I would highly recommend this hike!

This is a 5.5 mile out & back hike, according to my app. Great work out, amazing waterfall & view. Bring lots of water, it takes a little over 3 hours (break @ waterfall included) when hiking with children.

I just went on this trail today with a good friend of mine. Easily the best hike I've ever been on. Great scenery, wonderful friendly people, and a good overall workout with a great reward for making it halfway and to the end. It was a pretty easy hike, though there are some climbing areas. Last but not least, there is some great areas to rock climb no-gear if you are experienced enough, giving you a great view.

Much harder then I expected. The last quarter mile, after the bridge is much more difficult than the rest, although the first bit is steep. The hike, over all, is beautiful and worth the time spent. You do have to cross the water at the end to see the falls, either get your shoes wet or take them off for the last 50 feet. My children did the hike, youngest being 7. I thought he would beg to be carried, but he made it on his own the whole way up and back.

The trail begins with dusty switchbacks and quite a lot of dog poop.  You really need to watch where you step.   We went on a weekday and it was very crowded.  The scenery was beautiful, but I'd prefer to drive further into a canyon for a less traveled trail.
beautiful
One of my favorites. Easy to get to. trails easy to follow. Great to hike or run. Beautiful waterfall at top.

What a hike!  It was my first time hiking, so I didn't know what to expect terrain-wise and I've read the reviews before I decided on the Adam's Canyon trail. If dogs and children can do it, why not me? It's not as easy as it looks. The first 15 minutes or so were spent climbing uphill and then it levels out which is nice. I only did about half way before turning around because some of the terrains were rough and I'm pretty sure I need a walking stick to climb that terrain. Also, there were quite a few places that has water involved and water in my shoes wouldn't be good for hiking. So I'll just have to come back another time with proper equipment. Overall, it was a great hiking trail.
awesome trail along river and waterfalls. absolutely beautiful.
Great trail! Needs some help with dog poop removal by owners. But would definitely do it again in a heartbeat. The waterfalls are amazing!

great workout,  fun hike,  wonderful scenery,  waterfall at the end is great ...way too many people though.  go first thing during the week for less traffic.   it is much father than what this app indicates.  at least 5 miles round trip.

We did the first waterfall (family friendly route) and it was great! After about 10 switchbacks, take the 3rd right trail and you will make it to a secluded waterfall. About 1.5 miles round trip. We had two little kids with us and they did great!
Love this hike! Good workout!! Friendly people!
awesom

This trail was harder than I expected as it is tagged as easy on the page. There are some sandy switchbacks to start the hike which were rough, but then it leveled out for a bit. Towards the end it got really rocky and steep. Lots of people on the trail which made it hard to take it slowly. Due to time constraints I didn't make it to the top, but am going back again. Beautiful scenery!  Cool temps once you get in the canyon.
This trail is just south of Hill AFB. Very enjoyable incline and scenery.  Would bring extra socks as the trail crosses water on occasion.  Very popular so it can be crowded.
Steep trail with lots of water. Trail is shaded. It's a very popular trail so much so expect lots of hikers. Recommend waterproof shoes or water shoes for water crossing.

This was a great trail. Beautiful views, but way to many people on 
weekends.

Hiked this for the first time today with my wife and 16 month boy in a backpack. With 30 extra pounds on my back this was a hard hike with some difficult and steep areas of the trail. Watch your footing carefully because there are some loose rocks at times and as you get closer to the waterfall some wet areas, so it would be easy to slip. 

The first half mile is dusty switchbacks with no shade whatsoever. This was one of the worst parts of the hike. After the switchbacks you’ll hit a flat area for awhile and then you’ll be in the trees. From there most of the remainder of the trail is shady or partially shady. Much of the hike follows the stream so it’s cool and a nice respite from the heat. This is a great summer hike because it’s so shady. 

Along the way you’ll come across multiple areas of cascading water and smaller waterfalls, beautiful green forests, and overall some really great scenery. The final destination, the Adams Canyon Waterfall, is about 40 feet tall and is super spectacular. 

The trail was very busy today with lots of families with kids and lots of people with dogs. Unfortunately we came across evidence of multiple, inconsiderate dog owner’s who didn’t clean-up after their canine friends… So watch your step or you may dirty your boots… yuck.

This hike took us 2 hours and 47 minutes and according to the app Strava, it was 7.6 miles with 2,408 feet in elevation gain. I don't know why these numbers are so much different from the one's reported by AllTrails, but it seemed like a longer hike than the 3.8 miles reported…

We very much enjoyed this hike despite some difficult areas. The scenery was gorgeous, the view of the Great Salt Lake and Davis County was great, and the waterfall at the end was spectacular. Well worth your time. A+
our first hike of the year. Beautiful and perfect combo of difficulty and easy.
The lower portion of this trail (taking the right at the first fork) is easy and leads to a beautiful waterfall and pool of water to step in. Did this hike with an infant, 4 year old and a dog :)

Let me start by saying this was an absolutely beautiful hike! The views of the valley and the green hills were awesome. The creek is running very fast and you spend quite a lot of time by it which is nice. Now let me say, if you are a desk jockey like me, this will be a tougher trail. There are pretty good elevation gains and toward the top, you are climbing around the rocks. Nothing scary, just will give you a work out. Once you get near the falls, it is fairly steep and you have to cross the creek to see the actual falls. The best hint I saw on here was to take an extra pair of socks, right now you will need them after crossing. There were lots of people who appeared to be in far better shape than me who didn't appear to have much trouble with this. It was a lot of work for me, but the rewards were definitely worth it.
Amazing hike nothing to crazy definitely one of my favorites.

I hiked this trail with my 12 year old son. We liked it very well. The first half was very easy. It got more difficult as we got closer to the waterfall. In order to see the waterfall at the end we had to wade the creek, but it was well worth it. A spectacular fall!  It started raining and hauling on the way back out - making the rocks very slippery.  All in all a great hike. It took us about 70 minutes to get to the fall and about 45 minutes to hike back out.
It was just awesome!!!
Great trail. A lot of work with kids but well worth the view!  My dog had a blast. Can't wait to do this trail again.
Great hike, very vertical. The end is worth it!

We are definitely out of shape and still able to do this rugged trail. The waterfall is definitely a reward and worth getting wet for !!!

Don't pass up this beautiful walk with an amazing community of people.

The trail was great! Dog friendly and lots of variety. Heard a lot of good things about the trail, and thought it was time to explore it. It did not disappoint. It was a bit technical towards the top, but worth it. I gave it a four because it was a little to crowded for my taste.
Awesome Trail... Should be called up and down not out and back.:-)
Fantastic!!

Beautiful hike in the late afternoon and early evening. Water level was high with the spring runoff. Hike is easy to moderate depending on what kind of shape you are in. On our way out there were are a lot of people on the trail, youth groups, scouts, but everyone was very courteous. Definitely worth the time.

Great hike! I would definitely make sure to bring an extra pair of socks and shoes, as the only way to really see the waterfall is to cross the flow of water. Beautiful scenery. There is a little bit of climbing on rocks to get there, depending on which trail you take, but it was an incredible hike, and I'd definitely go again!
It is a great fun family hike. We went 2 weeks ago in early spring.  The waterfall was beautiful and full.
Fun trail that is well cared for.
Amazing!!
I liked it a lot and the waterfall was awesome at the end. It took my dog and I an hour and 15 round trip.
Loved all the nature and the friendly people on the trail as well!
Nice little hike. 30 min to the falls.
Good view of pretty much the entire salt lake. You can also head back into the mountain a little bit. Going to check it out again for sure.
great hike

wow, thought id take the fam (me wife 13 boy 8 boy 6 boy) on quick, short, hike. started late, 530. was going to return by 7 not at 9. the area just kept getting more and more awesome. ended up doing the whole hike. glad we did. waterfall was very cool. well worth it. so proud of boys. youngest had hard time up, but said he wanted to do it again. will do, just start early a.m.
decent short hike for an afternoon.  I'd rate it more to the easy side.  good early hike to stretch the legs.
It was a great hike. Taking a "shower" is really refreshing once you get there.
This trail was fun.  we camped over night.  saw the waterfall during the day.
Favorite hike in northern Utah in the 2-4 hour range. Not to challenging but you should have some good endurance, the worst part is absolutely the first set of switchbacks in sand.
An easy hike in the warm months. Quite tricky before all the snow melts. Very busy on the weekends. Beautiful canyon views the whole way up.

Excellent weather! Very beautiful with very little foot traffic. Completed this hike in ~2 hours roundtrip. Minor snow but didn't pose any obstacles. The waterfall was amazing and the view of the valley at the beginning is incredible!
Beautiful. The beginning is a little rough if you are out of shape like myself
Beautiful!!! Keep going to the very top! Cross the river on the left side and you can see the most beautiful sites!
accidently put my review on waterfall canyon, but they are the same. fun hikes, not for little kids!
Extremely fun hike with great scenery.  Love this trail and will definitely hike it again. Waterfall at the top was well worth it.
This was a fabulous way to spend a Saturday morn with my boy! Absolutely loved seeing all the different breeds of dogs along the way too! All good fun ... and beautiful!
Both lower & upper falls were beautiful. Fun hike.
Excellent hike. We went in late March and there was still snow near the top. It got pretty slick and dicey in some areas but it was a lot of fun. Go all the way to the top! It's worth it.
Fun, good little hike, but the waterfall isn't that impressive.
Wore running shoes. Not prepared for slick snowy parts. Still worth the bumps and bruises.
First time doing this trail, I like the trail but there are way to many people on it. Think I will stick with the less traveled trails.

I've been going up every week for the last month and it's a really a fun hike. There is still some snow on the upper half that running shoes, without extra grip, will be challenged. I used hiking boots and trail poles and it makes it easier. I was able to go up and down in about 2 hrs., but I was pushing it.
The waterfall is gorgeous in the winter but uses your snowshoes or crampons! Otherwise the hike can be exhausting and dangerous.

This is a beautiful trail, you can go there year round, we have been there in the summer and in the winter and it took us like 2 hours to go up all the way to the fall and about 1.5 hours to come back, we just went back for the second time now in January 2016 and it is beautiful with all the snow, specially the waterfall with all the ice.
Went November 14 2015 and super iced over in some spots. But very fun and cool temp.
Beautiful hike with a few different beautiful waterfalls!

This was my first time in Utah. I'm only in town for Comic Con this weekend and a local recommended this spot from "Vapor Affliction" (Rex). The hike was very enjoyable and the waterfall was a good reward. I had lunch at "Tosh's Ramen", (Tonkotsu w/Shiitake mushrooms), then I stopped by "Tulie Bakery" (banana tart and slow drip coffee) and ended the night with a Cold Cut Banh Mi from "No Mai"(as seen on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives).

This is one of my favorite hikes. I've done it about 15 times now. The beginning has sandy switchbacks that are a bit tiring but once you get past that and into the trees it's pretty much smooth sailing. The trail is pretty nice and shady from that point on as well. The last stretch of the hike is a bit more of an incline but The waterfall at the end is certainly a reward. You can even climb up the crevice by the waterfall all the way to the top of the mountain if you're up for it, although it's not part of the hike and it's pretty steep.
First trail that I have finished. Just started getting into hiking. Great trail and a great reward at the end loved the water fall!

It was an enjoyable hike, but the trail is, in my opinion, difficult.  Labor Day is not the best day to hike it.  I am sure there were at least 500 people on the trail.  Most were friendly and understood trail rules.  The falls are nice.  We decided we much prefer consistent trails like Mueller Park, even with all the bike riders.  You won't see any bikes on Adams, but you will see every kind of dog known to man.  Nice way to spend the morning.

Great hike.  Definitely not an easy hike.  I was surprised as we passed 3 families with children younger than 6.  Very dog friendly as well.  People were patient and friendly.  I took my 14 and 10 year old and it was not too challenging for them.

Fun, quick hike! When we got to the falls we scrambled up the dry rock side and had a great view!!!
We started late afternoon so we could catch sunset on the way out. Excellent trail for running!

This is a great hike, and the waterfall at the end is amazing!! This is NOT an easy hike. For about 3/4 of the way it is easy, but the last 1/4 becomes quite steep with several rock scrambles, so be prepared. Also, I think that this is a hike that is best done in the summer/fall. You follow the river very closely at some points and I am sure when there is snow melt the river become quite high.
Great time-- even with 5 little ones in tow-- we all enjoyed it!  The Falls were beautiful!!!
My kids and I really enjoyed this trail.
Good afternoon hike!
Beautiful, rugged, but lots of people.
Muddy.  Hard, rocky and uneven terrain in most parts.  The waterfall is pretty, but not the hike.  This trail is NOT EASY.
Nice!!!

This trail is very dog friendly - there's water almost the whole way - but can be pretty crowded, especially on weekends. I would not call it difficult, more moderate, but the waterfall at the end is definitely worth the trip at least once! I haven't done it in over a year but it's generally one we try to do every summer or fall.
It's tiiiiiight

This was a good hike I recommend early in the morning if you have a dog. The sand is pretty rough on their paws we had to carry our 65 pound dog down the bottom part of the trail because how hot it was in the afternoon!

It was a great hike! We started the trail at 9 and the sandy part was almost all in the shade. Once you hit the canyon it cools off from the breeze over the water and is almost all in the shade. There are parts that are pretty steep and rocky. It was easier to go up than down! 

It is definitely worth making it to the top! The falls are amazing. The water is super chilly even in August. But it was extremely refreshing after the uphill climb.

Adam's Canyon is great hike to a beautiful waterfall. It's hard to believe that a trail that starts so close to a busy road can take you to a waterfall deep in a canyon only 1.8 miles later. It involves a little more elevation gain that most of the waterfalls in Utah, but it's totally worth it. Adam's Canyon is a popular hike that only takes a couple of hours to do.

For pictures and more information on this hike, visit http://www.yourhikeguide.com/adams-canyon/
Excellent

This hike may be a little too difficult for beginners or little kids. the parking lot is small. we're just lucky that we got the last spot available when we arrived.  the entrance of the trail is in a residential area. I almost thought that we were at the wrong place. 

The first half mile or so of the hike is not shaded. So make sure you put a lot of sunscreen before you do this hike. We've seen a couple of snakes on the trail. the first one we was is a small snake on the side of the trail. the second on is a bigger one - probably 4 feet long. so be cautious. once you pass the the hill, most of the parts of will be shaded. it's a little difficult i would say since there are narrow and rocky paths. we stopped halfway to rest and take pictures of course. we saw a fallen log and walked through it to cross the beautiful stream. took beautiful pictures there. after 10 -15 mins, we continued our hike. it was a rocky hike. before hitting the end of the trail, we had to go through a steep rocky trail to get the falls. then we crossed the stream to get to a good resting place close to the falls. be prepared to get your shoes/feet wet. We always bring flip-flops on our hike to soak our tired feet into the water and take pictures of course closer to the falls. Gotta warn you though...the water is ICE cold. 

Overall, it was a beautiful hike. the waterfalls is a great reward after the tiring hike.
Awesome!!

I completed this trail on a Sunday afternoon with my brother and my dog.  It took about three or so hours round-trip.  The trail is mostly uphill and shaded with a few flat areas to rest or cool down, if needed.  The last part of the hike is more challenging as you will need to climb rocks.  Having shoes with decent traction will be helpful, especially when coming down.  There were mostly twenty-somethings and families, but it didn't feel overly-crowded.  It was dog-friendly and everybody we encountered was friendly and courteous.
Wonderful trail. My dog and kids loved it.

My dad and I hiked Adam's Canyon this morning and I would rate this trail as moderately difficult, not easy. The incline of the trail doesn't stop but once in a while you have a few flat areas. Once you reach the canyon it's gorgeous with a nice breeze. We hiked near the stream and climbed up and up. There was one treacherous area where I was afraid of climbing down. Thankfully my dad found us an alternative way to get down by the stream. Whew! We hiked about 3.5 miles or more total and definitely burned some serious calories. Can't wait to do it again and make it to the waterfall!
Beautiful waterfall! I took my dog and she loved it.  This is a great hike for families.

It was great! I went a couple weeks ago and I loved it. I made it up the trail in a little less than an hour, but my friend and I were booking it. We went very fast on the way up. It took us about a half an hour to get down. 

Some tips:
-Bring sunscreen. That's a no brainier. 
-If you bring a dog, make sure it's people friendly. There are usually other people on the trail. 
-The very first part of the trail is very hot, and there is sand. I wore white running shoes....I would t recommend doing that because they were brown by the end. But, my running shoes also were very fast drying. That was nice because there is a waterfall at the top that you have to cross some water to get to; my shoes were dry by the time I got done with the entire hike. 
-Going under the waterfall is well worth it if you're hiking in the summer! It cools you down for the entire way down. 
-Bring water and a snack!
Nice trail with some challenging points.  Love the waterfall
Not too hard. If you are taking kids, make sure you have plenty of water on hand.
Awesome! Cool canyon hike even in the 100 degree temps.
Great hike. We'll do it again.

Hiked this Saturday! My dog and I loved it!  BUT- the sand on the first .75 miles is REALLY hot.  Make sure you go early in the day or bring doggy booties (like I did) so your dog doesnt burn their paws!  A little bit of rock scrambling in some parts but a great workout with water for my dog to drink, and the falls were gorgeous.  And the shade was great!  Just need to get past the .75 miles of hot sand and switch backs. 

Great pictures and details on my blog! 
http://www.katiewanders.com/2015/06/adams-canyon-trail-waterfall-hike-dog.html

Another great trail in the awesome state of Utah! The 'chairs' up at the top are so cool! I also hiked up to the very top of the ridge, which provided an even more astonishing view of the valley! I found it a little difficult at the beginning, just because there are so many trails, but it wasn't that big of a deal.
One of my favorite trails,  Don't be scared off by the first part with all the switch backs, because once you get past that, the trail is amazing. Makes for some beautiful water pictures.

This hike is fantastic! The hike is pretty easy going, until the last 1/4 of a mile or so where you get to climb over rocks. It's not too bad, though! The waterfall is gorgeous!!! Also, this was my first time using this app and I was pleased that it led me straight there!
It's beautiful!
great hike. my brother and I try to do it once a year.

Great hike for almost all ages.  There are a few spots near the top where you should watch kids closely, but nothing too major.  Don't let the first section of switchbacks scare you away, because it could be the worst part.  On a hot day this part is pretty uncomfortable.  After that it's a steady climb in the trees with a great pay off at the falls.  Good trail if you haven't hiked in a while and want to get back into it.

Took my three kids up here on an overcast Friday morning. I heard the worst part was the sandy switchbacks at the beginning, but we made it through that all right. The hardest part for my kids was the last quarter mile, with numerous scrambling and hopping sections. I think an adult with a decent sense of balance would have no problem (although many adults were huffing and puffing, so be prepared for that), but the trail can be quite difficult for small kids due to scrambling and their shorter legs.
That being said, I loved the trail. My first time up here despite having lived in Utah for the past twenty years - I've avoided this one due to the crowds, but hiking it on Friday morning meant it had no more traffic than most other popular trails in the area. It was absolutely gorgeous - not only the waterfall, but the views and sections of the river when the trail got close by. Definitely worth the trip, but I would try to schedule for it an off day so you can enjoy the trip without too many crowds around.
First part is a little sandy seems like the trail is washing away but it's beautiful loved it went with husband mother in law and my little chihuahua everyone enjoyed it
This is a difficult trail, but doable. The waterfall is definitely worth the hike. The only thing I wish was different was that the path was clearly marked.
This was a beautiful hike!!! I will definitely do it again!!! The waterfall was amazing! It was a moderate difficulty level but my 6 year old did just fine!

Not sure I agree with the easy rating all trails has this at, but a great hike none the less. The beginning is pretty steep as you make your way up the switch backs, levels out for awhile and the some climbing up rocks towards the end. Wear quality shoes and take your time and you'll be fine.

I like hiking in all forms, but to have a nice hike to a great spot , to sit and enjoy and then come back from  is like complete satisfaction to me. 
I took 4 of my kids ranging from 12 down to 4.  All loved it, as did our dog. I have taken many cub scout groups on it as well. You can take it slow and easy, look at snakes, bugs and play in the water along the way, or take off up the rocks if looking for more challenging exercise.
  It is just a perfect hike.
Done this with my husband and our 7 year old. Really great trail!!! My son done excellent on this too.

This was a fun morning hike. It was SUPER busy when I got there, but everyone was so spread out, it never felt crowded. I got there at 10:30am and there were about 25 cars and when I left, there was at least 50. It took about an hour and twenty minutes to water =fall and 50 minutes to get back down. You have to do a bit of rock climbing at the end, but the waterfall is worth the extra effort. Also watch out for snakes - there was a nice big one in the sandy area at the beginning of the trail.
Such an amazing hike!! My dog loved it.

This is a difficult hike but well worth it. I took my dog and 2 kids, 10 years old, and we made it all the way up in about 2 hours. The last half is more rock climbing but it's still fun. There were plenty of people on the trail and I saw plenty of little ones too but I don't think my 6 year old daughter would have even made it half way. If you take your time it's a good challenging trail.

Wow, one of the most beautiful hikes I've done in the northern Wasatch front (lived here less than a year!)
The upper end of the canyon can be chilly as it is deep and shaded. Even on a Tuesday there were around 12 cars at the trailhead - don't expect solitude!
Great time of year for this hike as it was in the 60s and only enough snow and ice to make it interesting.

Completed this hike in the summer.  Adams Canyon Trail can get crowded so you may want to save this one for a weekday.  The trail can get rocky and at small sections require some easy rock scrambling.  Watch for snakes.

Love this hike.  Did it yesterday and today ....couldn't make it to the waterfall (almost) because I had my 7month old strapped to me in a Carrier and towards the end it was icy and dangerous (with an infant ). But I heard the waterfall was spectacular....was busy...but people are very friendly !

On a 60 degree day in mid winter we trekked through the mayhem of hundreds if not 1000s of hikers, families and dogs. It was so busy you needed traffic controllers. Apart from poor timing the hike itself was great. A little tougher than the blue rating I thought because of the constant inclines. Better when you break off the main trail for finding the less traveled road :)
Awesome Hike!  No snow at all until the very end, and even then there really wasn't much at all.

I just did this around 11A, and there were 3 others that I ran into within a period of three hours. This was nice, however; the ice for the latter part of the trail was pretty shady. Slipped a few times on the way up and down. Totally worth it to sit alone in the canyon, in the presence of the waterfall and eat some lunch. Little difficult for a beginning hiker, but totally worth it at your own pace. Can't wait to do this one in the summer!
We hiked this trail on a Sunday morning in January and only saw 1 other person. It is beautiful in the winter. Very peaceful.

This was an amazing hike. It was a bit difficult on the way up - be careful of the rocks - so I'd suggest an early start and plenty of water. But you weave back/forth across the river before ending up at the waterfall. There are lots of great places to stop and rest if you need to. I saw a lot of people on the trail who didn't make it to the waterfall - some only a few minutes away from it. Such a shame as this is a gorgeous little fall and the water was so refreshing. I saw lots of families too, but I don't know if my kids on all the rocks. Some kids we're having an easier time than others. All in all - a great day hike.
It was overall a good hike. Harder with little ones, but workable if you have help.

Decided to take this hike on my last afternoon in town, and was so glad I did. Not as strenuous as some of the others I did recently while in SLC, but the falls and the canyon scenery once clear of the shoreline trail were really very beautiful, especially considering the high amount of traffic on this trail.

There's a nice bouldering/ready free climb opportunity around the falls, and the view from up top is great. Thanks to the nice folks who left a sturdy fixed rope along the cleft that goes to the top of the falls!

Picked up a lot of small trail trash on this route (a full doggie poo bag, really?)...except for the dog bag, not a gripe (little kids need to hike, too!); just be ready to help keep it clean if you're not busy with tots of your own.

I've hiked dozens of trails in the valley by myself and this is the first one I got genuinely lost on.  There are a myriad of trails to choose from over the decades of usage. The waterfall was lovely, but it was the descent I went astray.  Sure it's lovely but just left a bad taste in my mouth getting lost.  And a Subaru was broken into in the parking lot. Only one car but FYI.
loved this hike!
Very Beautiful hike...Worth the work to get to the waterfall!!!!

Super great! I TOTALLY recommend it!
It's not a real tough hike, though it does have up hill parts. But if you get tired there are plenty of places that you can stop to take a break. I recommend going in the morning so it's cooler and less crowded and remember to bring lots of water and a camera to take pictures of the BEAUTIFUL waterfall at the end!

This is a great canyon to hike.  There are a few difficult parts, but overall it's not too hard if you take your time.  We usually hike it rather quickly with kids and it takes us about 2 hours up and back.  If it's your first time, take your time and enjoy the river, steep canyon walls, and great waterfall at the top.  Bring some snacks and have a little lunch at one of the campsites along the way up.

A nice trail. We did it on a Sunday, and although it was crowded we had fun. We took our dog off-leash and came across many other dogs along the way. It's definitely a great hike if you have a dog. It runs along a creek for most of the way, and ours loved playing in the water as we hiked. There's a waterfall at the top which was a nice place to stop, relax for a bit, and have a snack. The trail was fairly well-defined for the whole way. There is a small "trail" from the base of the waterfall to the top, but unless you're experienced it's quote dangerous, and I wouldn't recommend taking it even if you are, just in case someone takes a tumble and brings you down with them. We saw so many people attempt it who clearly had no idea what they were doing. But anyhow, lovely light afternoon hike. It took us about 3 hours round trip, and we were going at a pretty leisurely pace.
This has to be my favorite day hike in Utah to date. The hike itself is relatively easy and there are plenty of stops along the way worthy of photographs and lasting memories.
I LOVED this hike. Gorgeous! Following the creek was amazing. Pretty waterfall at the end!

I hiked this trail on 5/17.  It was extremely crowded, but still an excellent experience.  It was our (me and my daughter, Amy) first time to visit.  If you are going, you really need to stick with it till you get to the big waterfalls.  There is a smaller one about 15-20 minutes from the big one.  Water shoes are OK.  But the water is not deep and you can rock-hop to get to the big waterfall.  I highly recommend it!

Hiked this with my 2 little girls. I've gone on a Sunday and saw maybe 8 people. This time we went On a Saturday it was super crowded but the WATERFALL was amazing. A little strenuous toward the top for my girls but they did it !!! Bring water shoes you have to go across the river to see the waterfall

The first time hiking this trail can be confusing in some areas. Thankfully it isn't hard to find your way up if you just track the boot prints of humans and paw prints of dogs. Loved the hike. It had the perfect amount of challenging inclines and obstacles, and a bonus round at the very end - finding a rock path across the river. Or not worrying about it and just trudging through the river. Either way, you're going to get your shoes/feet wet. As always bring water and other outdoor gear you feel necessary for a 2-3 hour excursion.
This was a great hike! Took six kids along with us ranging from four years old to 10 years old. Not too hard but still a fun challenge. Will definitely do it again.
For all you people Bitching about dogs being off the leash.. if you google "Layton Utah off the leash dog hike" Adams canyon trail is the first thing to pop up.

This trail has a few awesome faces to get up. Some great points to anchor in and get a great climb also good free climb spots as well. Right after the small fall that goes over the big boulders is a sweet cliff! Not for amateur climbers! At the waterfall there is some good bouldering and a great place to get your lunch on.  A side note keep your dogs on a leash! No one cares if "he's the sweetest. oh he'll never bite. He's trained" its the law. No one wants to be nocked over on the rocks because your dog is bolting along the trail.

His trail was great. I was looking for something new and I ran into this. It was hard but fun. And the waterfall is gorgeous. The parking was pretty easy and it isn't hard to find the area. I enjoyed the scenery and the fact that my dogs could get out for a bit and play in the river. It was all in all a great hiking I'll be doing more often.
I went on the hike. It was beautiful. I took my dog, on a leash of course. But lots of inconsiderate people with dogs off leash. I had 4 children with me. They all loved it. Fun hike very pretty.
Solid hike. The last quarter can get pretty hairy  the trail narrows and gets quite rocky  but it's worth it.

This is by far one of my favorite trails.  I hike here several times a week when time permits.  The hike can be difficult based on the route taken.  Some of the obstacles can be avoided by going around them.  That is what I have my small children do when we go together.  It can get crowded especially on weekends and evenings.  The biggest complaint from people I know is the dog owners.  Please be respectful and keep you dog on a leash.  I'm sure your dog is wonderful but dogs fight.  I have seen several altercations on the trail because of unleashed dogs.  The other big complaint is the constant smell of dog poop along the bottom of the trail.  Basic trail etiquette is definitely lacking.

I enjoyed this hike, but there are a lot of inconsiderate people that have their dogs off their leash.  I brought my boxer, but I had her on a leash and I also brought supplies to clean up after her.  WATCH YOUR STEP to avoid all the doggie doo doo on the trail.

Fun hike, but lots of people. When you get to the top, there is an area where you can do some bouldering up above the waterfall. The trail follows the river almost the whole way which is nice and refreshing. Be prepared for other hikers that have their dogs with them. Also, the first section of the hike consists of a very sandy trail that switches back multiple times. Once you are past that it is great!

It's up up up, followed by down down down, LOL!!!!   I'm from Oregon where we don't have snakes, and I was a little concerned about running into one.  Didn't see any though.  Plenty of friendly people to say 'hello' to on the trail.

Pretty fun hike.. used to try and run it top to bottom, when there aren't so many people.  A few years ago I came down the trail pretty late as the sun was setting, right when all the rattlesnakes came out.. I counted 4-5 before I saw one in the trees right next to a turn in the trail, and he was like, waist high to me.. pretty scary in the trees... About 10 feet in front of me was a little boy, about 6-7 all by him self.  I told the boy to hurry and catch up to his family... which I couldn't even see on the trail..  They were about 400 yards past their kid and had no idea.  I told the mom she needed to keep a look out for snakes, which she sneered "in Utah? .. we don't have any snakes in Utah"   Attention people who hike in Utah.. snakes are real.  And yes, we have them in Utah.
It's really not that great of a hike. You would be better off going a little more north. Way better hiking up towards Ogden.
Camped up here on the north side above the canyon on an outcropping of rocks over looking kaysville.  Hiked down and went to the waterfall at about midnight- totally awesome

First, this is a beautiful hike. Second, this hike sucks due to the sheer overwhelming amount of people on the trail. It gets worse- people with dogs off leash running up and down narrow rocky trails, parents with toddlers taking 10 minutes to get them up a rocky incline, people not following basic trail etiquette, lines of people bottle-necking at inclines. Not to mention mountain bikers on a trail that is set aside for hikers. Id like to give this trail four stars and maybe its a four star trail on a weekday when everyone is at work or in school but on a Saturday or Sunday- forget it; its a waste of time!

Its a really great hike! I am not a huge fan on really groomed trails but once you get farther on the trail it becomes less groomed. It's got a beautiful over look of the city at night and you can see the Salt Lake and all the way to the Tooele mountains. It was way fun! I recommend it to anyone. The beginning of the trail is a little steep and that is probably why its rated as moderate/harder but once you get down by the river it is stunning. A lot of large fallen trees that crisscross the river.

The trail was very enjoyable- fairly steep with not much to look at for the first mile or so, but then it hooks up with a stream with various waterfalls along the way.  I had to stop just shy of 2 miles as the trail was covered with snow/ ice towards the top.

I like Adams Canyon.  I love the falls at the end but I also enjoy the trails that can go beyond the falls.  I wouldn't hike this until all the snow is gone in the mountains as once you pass the bridge there can be some dangerous ice patches.  I am able to do this hike in about 3 hours with my toddler on my back.  The only part I do not like about this trail is the sandy switchbacks in the beginning.  Normally I take the trails on the side of the switchbacks, but I cannot do that safely with my toddler.

Pretty and quick spring hike at a low elevation with a 1200 ft total gain. Water rushing hard now due to snow melt and it is absolutely stunning. 
Thought that going on Easter would make for some solitude but seems everyone else thought the same thing and the trail was hopping! If you go anyime in the next week or so you will encounter snow and ice in the last quarter mile - bring your micro spikes if you want to make it to the waterfall.
Nice hike close to town so not a lot of driving.  Well worth it at the end is a beautiful waterfall which is refreshing to cool off in on a hot summer hike.

Awesome hike! A little challenging towards the top, but well worth it. One of the biggest waterfalls I have seen in utah. 

If you are taking dogs I would recommend starting early (before noon). The trail is sandy for the first half, after the sand sites in the sun it gets extremely hot. We went around 1pm and the sand began to burn the dogs feet. So, either start early, have your dogs wear booties, or if the dogs are small just carry them past the sand.
Lots of fun! Just finished w/ my 8 & 10 year old boys.

The trail is supper busy, and fairly technical (climbing over trees, scrambling up dirt hill sides, crossing freezing water)  Don't let this scar you away, if you want to do it you can make it even while caring a kid in a pack.  There is not good place to get fresh water, no bathroom.

I've done this one three times.  The first time was with some friends.  The second time was with my older son and the third time was with my wife.  Each time was a lot of fun.  The scenery is beautiful once you get up the winding part of the trail.  The waterfall was really cool and a very much needed reward at the end.  I would highly recommend doing this one.  It can get crowded at times, though

We hit Adams trail after hiking Waterfall Canyon and we got the blast furnace effect on the initial climb in the sand and it was hot! But once we hit the half way point, if you can call it, and started into the forest, it got a bit cooler but the trail got steeper and rockier. Near the top, the trail seemed to have multiple paths but we followed the one with the most use and came out at the waterfalls and it was worth the trip. Even though the trail was in the Wasatch, I was amazed at how dry it was despite following a stream up to the falls. Came across a couple of wasps gatherings but they did not bother us as we passed through. Great hike and we want to try  it when it is not so hot.

Most of the elevation gain is at the beginning of the hike, which is sandy with lots of switchbacks. Once you pass the switchbacks you have access to the Bonneville Shoreline trail to the north, or you can continue into the canyon to the waterfall. Definitely do this hike in the AM, or late afternoon since there is minimal shade until you get into the canyon itself. Other hikers were friendly and helpful.

I loved this hike! It was a little tough with some rock climbing. The waterfall at the end was gorgeous! The small waterfall over these enormous holders before you reach the waterfall was pretty! Two thumbs up for this hike! Amazing! Watch out for your children due to some rock climbing on the path. My 10 year old loved it. Just keep your babies and pets close.

This is a beautiful hike! The first half mile is is pretty steep as it is steep uphill climb in the sand. You feel like you're in the desert. It eventually flattens out and there are lots of creeks and trees that helps with the heat. Dogs are allowed on this trail. As long as You follow the water, you will find the waterfall.  There are many trails on this hike that will lead you to a Dead end. I've seen a lot of parents that had to turn around because their kids couldn't make it to the waterfall or couldn't climb the steep hill. The waterfall is spectacular! Definitely have a photo-shoot there!

The views of the Salt Lake are gorgeous on this hike! The first half of the hike has little shade and plentiful sunshine, so come prepared. Once trail users get to the trees, the temperature drops significantly. Overall, the trail is beautiful and not too difficult.

My Family did this on April 8th - memorable because my son was born the following day!  I guess I shouldn't have brought my wife all the way up there :-)  It does get a bit rocky and difficult toward the top.

Very nice hike, not that difficult after the first 1/4 mile.  The trail is very busy even late at night. I brought my 4 year old and she had to take a few breaks along the way getting there.  She made it all the way there without being carried.  There are a few steep spots and areas are very rocky.  We camped over night, not great campsites.  There are only a few places to camp and are very, very close to the trail some site even have the trail through the middle. There were people walking through our site till about 10pm.  If you camp just keep an eye on your gear because of all the foot traffic. Otherwise we had a good time. She even ran most of the way back.
Beautiful views and really nice people on the trail. The parking lot was completely full and we had to park down the road.

I am military and my wife and I just PCS'd here in November. This was our second hike here (we did birdsong, as a warm-up). I loved it... the perfect mix of challenge and reward. I like how the trail travels through the forest and is relaxing and shady (at times), other times it feels like your going straght up. We had a really great time. My only regret is we didn't bring a camara.

One of my favorite hikes. Lots of greenery, instead of rocks like up waterfall canyon. I go up several times a year. The views are gorgeous. Great hike! Very shaded. Pretty waterfall up top. About a 4 hour hike, maximum.

I took my six year old son on this hike twice now. Yesterday I went at his pace completely.  We made it up to the falls in 36 minutes.  We made it back to the trailhead in 29 minutes.  This trail does have a few rocky places and places where falling is possible, but what hike doesn't.  Children can do this hike if they are under cautious supervision.  The trail is, in my opinion, of moderate difficulty.  However, i am in good physical condition.
Beautiful hike and waterfall. well worth it.

I have hiked Adams Canyon several times and have enjoyed the hike each time. This time of year the canyon was not full of hikers as usual. The start of the trail is a bit strenuous, but as you get to the top of the switchbacks it eases into a nice climb up to the water fall.  Once you start into the canyon the trail is shaded as you hike along the creek. There a  couple of places where you navigate around some rock outcroppings but it is still a nice hike. Good family hike.

This was our first time for Adams Canyon and it was awesome. We did it with our 9 and 6 year old and they did great until we were almost back. The last section before the falls is very steep and requires extreme care but it is definitely worth it.
Fun little trail.  We had a great time.  Nice waterfall at the end.

We had a great time hiking to this falls in this canyon. We were fortunate to meet some folks coming down the trail that told us to keep going and to step out into the stream to get the full effect of the falls. It was a very pleasant hike.

With the exception of the sandy switchbacks at the very beginning of the trail, this trail is absolutely awesome!  It's long enough that you really feel like you got a good workout but very easily done in an afternoon.  It has a very nice combination of easy, moderate and difficult.  There is a lot of shade.  You don't have to do the entire hike in order to get the great scenery.  The waterfall at the top has a pool at the bottom of the fall about 12 inches deep-deep enough to take a very refreshing dip at the end of the long, tiresome hike.  If you plan on doing the entire hike, I wouldn't recommend this for parents with kids under the age of 10.  Perfect "date hike."

Nice trail sometimes too busy, instead of going in the canyon there are some awesome destinations on the North and South Rims of the Canyon.  Cabins that are open to a nights stay.  Good luck, finding them is half the battle if you have never been there.  Good family hike and do watch out for rattlers, usually not a problem at all either.

I did this once this morning, and again in the afternoon, great trail, but like others have said, the switchbacks are rough, mostly because of the loose sand/silt/dirt on that part of the trail.  After that the rough parts are what you would expect from a canyon hike next to a creek, rocks, water edging and crossing, but well worth it once you hit the top and get to the falls, which are a great place to re-stretch and take a breath before heading down again.
Great trail...make sure u either go first thing in the morning or evening. Can be very hot...no cover cover for shade in first portion of the trail.
I love this trail and do it all the time with my boyfriend and his family. The water fall at the end is beautiful and the hike up there isnt too bad either.

In the short time I have been here in Kaysville I have done Adams Canyon three times.  It's a must do trail.  Good workout getting up the initial switchbacks at the beginning of the trail...but so rewarding when you hit the wooded area and start your assent up the canyon along the creek.  You then get a second workout after you cross the creek and have to literally climb rocks to the waterfall.  I think the best part is having to walk through the creek at the end to see the upper 40' waterfall.  Don't miss the lower waterfall which is off to the south at the top of the switchbacks.  There is a trail located between the BST (Bonneville Shoreline Trail) and the switchbacks that takes you south down to the creek.  There is another hidden 15' - 20' waterfall that is just as beautiful as the upper fall.  After the lower fall you have to take the trail back up to the switchbacks and then back to the trail head as the trail down from the lower falls dumps you into the housing track below.

First hike out of the bag for a few years, switch backs up from parking lot certainly get you going. Take a right fork to the first waterfall, definitely worth a visit. Then back on the main trail, over a small wooden bridge to the second waterfall at the end of the Canyon. The last hundred meters is harder going and there was still some snow on the ground, which made conditions a little trecherous. But the final waterfall is well worth the climb.
It is nice that is it so close by. Still a little bit of a workout to get there.
Really nice scenic hike. Follows a creek almost the whole way up to a really cool waterfall. Though parts of trail can be a bit steep and demanding overall it's a relatively easy hike.
